018package org.opengis.filter;
019
020import java.util.List;
021import org.opengis.annotation.UML;
022
023import static org.opengis.annotation.Obligation.MANDATORY;
024import static org.opengis.annotation.Specification.ISO_19143;
025
026
027/**
028 * A character string comparison operator with pattern matching.
029 * {@code LikeOperator} performs the equivalent of the SQL "{@code LIKE}" operator on properties of a feature.
030 * The pattern contains a combination of regular characters, the {@linkplain #getWildCard() wildcard character},
031 * the {@linkplain #getSingleChar() single character}, and the {@linkplain #getEscapeChar() escape character}.
032 * The wildcard character matches zero or more characters.
033 * The single character matches exactly one character.
034 * The escape character is used to escape the meaning of the wildcard, single character and escape character itself.
035 *
036 * @author  Chris Dillard (SYS Technologies)
037 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
038 * @version 3.1
039 * @since   3.1
040 *
041 * @param  <R>  the type of resources (e.g. {@link org.opengis.feature.Feature}) to filter.
042 */
043@UML(identifier="LikeOperator", specification=ISO_19143)
044public interface LikeOperator<R> extends ComparisonOperator<R> {
045    /**
046     * Returns the nature of the comparison.
047     * The default implementation returns {@code PROPERTY_IS_LIKE}.
048     *
049     * @return the nature of the comparison.
050     */
051    @Override
052    default ComparisonOperatorName getOperatorType() {
053        return ComparisonOperatorName.PROPERTY_IS_LIKE;
054    }
055
056    /**
057     * Returns the expression whose values will be compared by this operator, together with the pattern.
058     * The list content is as below:
059     *
060     * <ol>
061     *   <li>The first expression provides the values to compare. It should evaluate to a character string.</li>
062     *   <li>The second expression is the pattern. It is often specified in a {@link Literal} with a value which
063     *       is a combination of regular characters, the {@linkplain #getWildCard() wildcard character}, the
064     *       {@linkplain #getSingleChar() single character}, and the {@linkplain #getEscapeChar() escape character}.</li>
065     * </ol>
066     *
067     * @return a list of size 2 containing the expression to be compared and the pattern, in that order.
068     */
069    @Override
070    @UML(identifier="expression", obligation=MANDATORY, specification=ISO_19143)
071    List<Expression<R,?>> getExpressions();
072
073    /**
074     * Returns the character that can be used in the pattern to match any sequence of characters.
075     * The default value is the {@code "%"} character.
076     *
077     * @return the character for matching zero or more characters.
078     */
079    @UML(identifier="wildCard", obligation=MANDATORY, specification=ISO_19143)
080    default char getWildCard() {
081        return '%';
082    }
083
084    /**
085     * Returns the character that can be used in the pattern to match exactly one character.
086     * The default value is the {@code "_"} character.
087     *
088     * @return the character for matching exactly one character.
089     */
090    @UML(identifier="singleChar", obligation=MANDATORY, specification=ISO_19143)
091    default char getSingleChar() {
092        return '_';
093    }
094
095    /**
096     * Returns the character that can be used in the pattern to prefix one of the wild card characters
097     * to indicate that it should be matched literally in the content of the feature's property.
098     * The default value is the {@code "\"} character.
099     *
100     * @return the character for escaping a wildcard character.
101     */
102    @UML(identifier="escapeChar", obligation=MANDATORY, specification=ISO_19143)
103    default char getEscapeChar() {
104        return '\\';
105    }
106
107    /**
108     * Specifies how a filter expression processor should perform string comparisons.
109     * A value of {@code true} means that string comparisons shall match case.
110     * The value {@code false} means that string comparisons are performed caselessly.
111     * The default value {@code true}.
112     *
113     * @return {@code true} if comparisons are case sensitive, otherwise {@code false}.
114     */
115    // Defined in OGC corrigendum, not yet in ISO 19143 (as of 2010 revision).
116    default boolean isMatchingCase() {
117        return true;
118    }
119}
